keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 killing of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
The execution was the second of the year in Arizona and the fourth in the U.S. this week, reflecting ongoing national activity in the death penalty.
Djerf claimed to have been driven by revenge over a prior theft, and the prosecution alleged he sexually assaulted and murdered the victims in a violent, systematic manner.
The execution process took about 10 minutes, with the IV insertion being difficult due to suboptimal veins, and the state has faced criticism for delays in past executions.
Arizona has faced repeated criticism and pauses in its execution program since 2014 due to concerns about botched procedures and ethical concerns about the death penalty.
The state last executed a prisoner in March 2025, and with Djerf’s execution, now has 107 prisoners on death row.
The execution occurred without victim representatives present and Djerf did not make a final statement, though he had previously apologized in a released statement.
Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes supported the execution, stating the victims and their families deserve justice and closure.
The death penalty in Arizona is part of a broader national context, with five more executions scheduled in the U.S. this year across Florida, Alabama, Oklahoma, and Tennessee.
The state's execution procedures were reviewed and changed in 2024, following a pause in 2023 and a political review led by Governor Katie Hobbs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Phoenix, Arizona, on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, Rochelle Luna (18), and Damien Luna (5), which he committed in retaliation for a theft he blamed on a family member, Albert Luna Jr. The execution was the second in Arizona that year and the fourth in the U.S. this week, following years of pauses due to procedural issues and public criticism. Officials including Attorney General Kris Mayes and Deputy Director John Barcello emphasized that the victims’ families deserve justice and closure. The process, which took about 10 minutes and involved multiple IV attempts due to poor vein access, highlighted ongoing concerns about the state’s execution procedures, especially after a 2014 botched execution of Joseph Wood. The execution resumed in 2022 after a review paused in 2023, with Governor Katie Hobbs ending the review in November 2024. Djerf had previously apologized in a statement, and no family members were present. The execution increased Arizona’s death row population to 107, with five more executions scheduled across the U.S. in 2025.
